medicalhistoryepisode.patientmedicalcomment: IgG Multiple myeloma with lytic lesions and compression fractures at T8 and T10, bone marrow 50%plas
Bone survey showed compression fractures in thoracic spine. Degenerative changes in spine.
40 years smoking (35 pack year) - quit smoking in 1997 and quit "tobacco use" in Oct 2006
Progression of lytic lesion of spine. destructive lesion of the sacrum.
Angioplasty and stenting of thrombosed right common iliac artery for history of atherosclerotic peri
Underwent laminectomy secondary to lytic lesion related to multiple myeloma.
Tip in the upper aspect of the superior vena cava.

reaction.primarysourcereaction: Exposed area of necrotic bone with the margin of the mandible slightly irregular
Fungating left submandibular neck mass/palpable thickening under chin and mandible
Submental adenopathy/nodular site of granulation tissue beneath chin
Soft tissue masses in the left side of neck inferioir to mandible
Flares of local infection from the raised nodular site of granulation tissue beneath the chin
Multiple small lytic lesions in the skull
Compression fractures of T5, T8, T10
Calcification along the inferior border of the mandible
CT of neck has areas of sclerosis throughout the visualized spine suspicious for myeloma
Melanoma of the skin of the forehead
Melanoma of the skin of the forehead
Mildly displaced fractures of the lateral right 6th and 7th rib
Cyst in upper pole of kidney
Degenerative changes in the lower cervical spine
Patchy infiltrates at both lung bases
Osteoarthritis of first interphalangeal joint/ Degenerative changes in both shoulders
Osteomyelitis of left thumb \ Osteomyelitis of mandible
Mild distal first digit flexor and extensor tenosynovitis
Central canal stenosis at T4 level
Non calcified 9-mm diameter nodule at left lung apex/Small calcified lung nodules

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
01 Feb 2006 initial report received via a Sales Representative: A physician reported that a patient that had been administered Zometa (zoledronic acid) to treat multiple myeloma (no other regimen details specified) developed "ONJ" (osteonecrosis of the jaw) an unspecified time from commencing therapy on an unspecified date. The patient's condition was not specified.
07 Feb 2006 follow up received: The oncologist reported that this patient took Aredia (pamidronate disodium) from February 2002 until October 2003 90 mg monthly to treat myeloma and Zometa (zoledronic acid) from November 2003 until September 2005 3.5-4 mg monthly (no specification on when dose changes occurred) to treat myeloma. The oncologist described the adverse event as "possible osteonecrosis" (onset date not specified). The patient's condition was present and unchanged. The oncologist suspected a relationship between the event and therapy, however, he did not specify a rationale for this opinion.
30 May 2006 follow-up combined with follow-up from 31 May 2006: Oncologist reports that in approximately Sept 2005, the patient became aware of a thickening below his chin. Zometa therapy was interrupted. A MRI of the mandible dated 25 Oct 2005 was interpreted as showing ill defined soft tissue masses immediately inferior to the left side of the mandible along with prominent submental nodes and subperiostial collection of fluid or soft tissue. 3 Feb 2006, CT showed slight irregularity of the inferior margin of the mandible and submental adenopathy. The patient received antibiotics (not specified) on multiple occasions with transient improvement. The oncologist reported that he is suspicious that the patient has osteonecrosis of the mandible. 18 Jan 2006, metastatic bone survey again demonstrated multiple small lytic lesions in the skull and compression fractures of T5, T8, T10. The study was thought to be stable or perhaps slightly worse in the region of the skull. The patient has not received additional therapy directed at his myeloma since his autologous stem cell transplant.
05 Dec 2007: Upon receipt of follow-up via attorney inclusive of medical records from the oncologist and oral surgeon it was found that this case was a duplicate of PHEH2006US03611. PHEH2006US03611 will be deactivated and information will merged into this existing case. On 16 Mar 2006 a petition was received from patient's attorney which alleged that in response to receiving Aredia and Zometa this plaintiff developed osteonecrosis of the jaw with pain and suffering , mental anguish and the loss of enjoyment of life.
New information extracted from medical records received on 05 Dec 2007 is as follows: A 01 Nov 2005 note reported patient had a fungating left submandibular neck mass extending through the cutaneous tissue with surrounding erythema and edema. He was treated with amoxicillin/clavulanate 875 mg PO QD and wound treated with peroxide and polysporin ointment. A 30 Jan 2006 note reflected abnormalities in the neck and mandible seemed to have improved with antibiotic therapy (with resolution of tenderness and drainage) with symptoms recurring when antibiotics were interrupted. A 03 Feb 2006 CT of neck showed soft tissue thickening anterior to the mandible was less pronounced on comparison MRI of 25 Oct 2005. It was believed there was mild elevation of the periosteum which was similar to the prior MRI. The inferior margin of the mandible was slightly irregular and may have been involved by a myeloma or an infectious process. No well-defined destructive mass was seen. A partially illegible dental note of 23 May 2006 reported patient had osteonecrosis of the lower jaw due to Zometa and Aredia. Bone was deteriorating in jaw. A 30 May 2006 note reported patient was still struggling with chin/neck lesion related to osteonecrosis due to Zometa. Two lesions have healed but with dimpling of skin overlying area. Third lesion continued to occasionally drain yellow fluid and occasionally has bled. However lesion continued to gradually improve. A 07 Jul 2006 oral surgeon note reported patient originally underwent two marginal debridements of his left mandible to try to decrease the size of an exposed area of necrotic bone in this area. Unfortunately, due to the advanced state of periodontal compromise of teeth #20 and 21 it was unsuccessful in trying to do this with conservative therapy. At this point it was thought the only option to try to prevent the necrotic process from spreading throughout his mandible was to extract the teeth. Teeth were extracted ( 07 Jun 2006) with another marginal debridement in which soft primary tissue closure was done over the defect. On a follow-up visit the soft tissue closure had remained intact and that the patient was experiencing no discomfort in the area. A 19 Sep 2006 oncology note stated patient has been on prolonged oral penicillin therapy. He has had intermittent scant drainage. Flares of local infection were associated with discomfort but have resolved. Upon examination there was a raised somewhat nodular site of granulation tissue beneath the chin. Patient continued to show gradual improvement throughout Oct 2006 In Dec 2006 he had intermittent slight drainage from his jaw although he just completed a prolonged antibiotic course of treatment; later in Mar 2006 lesion was draining on a daily basis. By Jun 2007 there was noted improvement in jaw lesion with only occasional drainage. Patient denied associated pain. Upon examination, small open lesion noted under his chin with granulation tissue noted, however without obvious drainage.
18 Feb 2008: Follow-up information received via attorney inclusive of medical records from the Ear Nose and Throat (ENT) physician and treating dentist. New information extracted from these records is as follows: the patient received Aredia 90 mg IV monthly from Feb 2002 until 06 Oct 2003 for bony lytic lesions associated with IgG multiple myeloma. Patient then received Zometa 4mg IV monthly from 03 Nov 2003 until it was discontinued on 10 Oct 2005. On 08 Aug 2005, an x-ray of the mandible showed some calcification along the inferior border of the mandible with multiple small lucencies seen in the anterior aspect of the mandible. The finding was interpreted as suspicious for myelomatous involvement of the mandible although it was also noted that the appearance has also been seen with other destructive etiologies of the bone such as osteomyelitis or metastatic disease. A progress note on 19 Sep 2006 reported the patient had additional teeth removed (specific teeth and dates of extraction not specified) then received a course of oral penicillin. On 05 Dec 2005, the patient underwent biopsy of the submandibular neck mass. No pathology report was available at the time. ENT progress note reported the patient was treated with unspecified antibiotics after the biopsy. An examination of the area by the ENT revealed subtle submental fullness and three areas of "puckering," one of which is crusted. The patient denied pain or tenderness and reported some subtle drainage at times. The ENT indicated that the final diagnosis for the patient's submental jaw abnormalities were pending. On 30 Jan 2006, the ENT physician indicated that he had not made a precise diagnosis for the neck and mandible changes and stated these changes most probably reflect bisphosphonate induced osteonecrosis of the jaw. On 03 Feb 2006, a CT scan of neck showed areas of sclerosis throughout the visualized spine which are suspicious for myeloma. Upon follow-up on 15 Jun 2007, the patient reported occasional drainage involving his jaw and noted the area has continued to heal.
Follow up received 13 Apr 2009 from the consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Records dated 01 May 2002 indicated that the patient noted some arthralgia which seemed to worsen after administration of pamidronate.
Combined follow up reports received on 07 May 2012, 08 May 2012 and 09 May 2012 from consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records respectively. The patient's historical condition included bilateral cataract. The patient's current conditions included degenerative disc disease and disc protrusion. Record dated 19 Sep 2006 noted that patient was suffering from osteoporosis. Record dated 10 Sep 2009 noted that patient suffered from L5-S1 radiculopathy, right carpal tunnel syndrome and melanoma of the skin of the forehead. The patient underwent cataract extraction, polypectomy and excision of malignant melanoma from skin. Record dated 17 Jun 2010 noted that patient experienced recent upper respiratory infection. Chest X-ray dated 29 Jan 2011 showed left lower lobe pneumonia and pleural effusion. Record dated 07 Jun 2011 noted that patient was suffering from supraventricular tachycardia, pancytopenia and hyperlipidemia. The x-ray of rib dated 21 Jun 2011 showed mildly displaced fractures of the lateral right 6th and 7th rib. Record dated 14 Sep 2011 noted that patient was suffering from thumb cellulitis. Record dated 12 Mar 2012 noted that patient suffered from sequestrum and exposed bone in jaw. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up information received on 17 May 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: The medical record dated 22 Apr 2008 stated that the patient had dyspnea on exertion, chest pain, destructive bone lesions on chest. Record dated 04 Nov 2008 stated that the patient suffered with diverticulosis. Record dated 03 Jun 2011 stated that the patient noted with mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, mild aortic regurgitation was noted by color doppler, hypotension NOS and underwent deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis. Record dated 17 Aug 2011 stated that the patient had anemia multifactorial. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 27 Jun 2012 via a consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Records dated 13 Mar 2007 stated that the patient had benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH). Records dated 04 May 2010 stated that the patient had bleeding. Records further stated that the event of benign prostate hyperplasia was mild and got resolved. The outcome of the event bleeding was not reported.
Follow up received on 09 Jul 2012 via a consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Record dated 20 Jul 2004 noted that patient was suffering from cyst in upper pole of kidney, degenerative changes in the lower cervical spine and facet joint hypertrophy. Record dated 25 Nov 2009 noted that patient was suffering from patchy infiltrates at both lung bases. Record dated 11 Sep 2011 noted that patient was suffering from osteoarthritis of first interphalangeal joint. Record dated 12 Sep 2011 noted that patient was suffering from osteomyelitis of left thumb. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow up information received on 26 Jul 2012 from a physician via a consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: The patient's surgical history included lower back disc surgery and stem cell transplant. Record dated 03 Jun 2011 noted mild to moderate hypertension, yellowish phlegm, cough and mitral regurgitation. Record dated 06 Jun 2011 noted dizziness and dyslipidemia. Record dated 07 Jul 2011 noted fatigue and the electrocardiogram revealed atrial flutter. The patient also developed varicose veins, indigestion and loss of appetite due to Revlimid and Dexamethasone. Record dated 18 Nov 2011 noted vascular stent placement in right leg. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 30 Jul 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Record dated 02 Nov 2005 stated that the patient had acute epidermal and dermal inflammation. Record dated 09 Jan 2006 stated that the patient had swelling in the neck. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow up received on 07 Aug 2012 from physician via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Record dated 11 Sep 2011 noted pain in thumb. Record dated 12 Sep 2011 noted swelling in thumb and small blister. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow up received on 09 Aug 2012 from physician via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: Magnetic resonance of hand with or without contrast on dated 12 Sep 2011, showed skin thickening, hand abscess and mild distal first digit flexor and extensor tenosynovitis. X ray of chest dated 14 Sep 2011, revealed degenerative changes in both shoulders. Also, patient underwent the procedure of peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line placed with the tip in the upper aspect of the superior vena cava. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 31 Aug 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Record dated 20 Jul 2004 noted that patient had motor vehicle accident on an unspecified date. Record dated 06 Oct 2007 noted that patient suffered from redness in both eye, burning irritation in eye and diagnosed with bilateral conjunctivitis. Record dated 14 Sep 2011 noted that patient was suffering from thrombocytopenia. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 07 Sep 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Record dated 30 Dec 2008 noted that patient suffered from osteomyelitis of mandible and lesion within left parotid gland. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 05 Oct 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Patient's history included abscess of left thumb and axilla from methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in Sep 2011. No new medical information was provided.
Combined follow-up report received from the consumer's attorney on 22 Oct 2012, 23 Oct 2012 and 24 Oct 2012 inclusive of medical records. Record dated 01 Feb 2011 noted that the patient had thoracic tumor. Record dated 16 Feb 2011 noted that the patient had nasal abscess, nasal congestion and heartburn. Record dated 01 Mar 2011 revealed that the patient had secondary malignant neoplasm bone. Record dated 29 Mar 2011 noted that the patient had multiple myeloma, Ig G, progressive. Outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow-up received on 29 Oct 2012 via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. MRI thoracic spine dated 29 Jan 2011 revealed central canal stenosis at T4 level and spinal cord deformity. Record dated 21 Jun 2011 stated that the patient experienced fall. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Follow up received on 19 Nov 2012 via a consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records: CT scan of thorax dated 29 Jan 2011 showed non calcified 9-mm diameter nodule at left lung apex. The outcome of the event was not reported.
Follow up received on 07 Dec 2012 from physician via consumer's attorney inclusive of medical records. Record dated 21 Jan 2011 noted small calcified lung nodules. The outcome of the events was not reported.
Refer case ID PHEH2012US017652 created for Aredia.
summary.sendercomment: MAC: Review of available data reported in this legal case does not allow for proper causality assessments. Treatment dates with Zometa and Aredia are not reported. Some conditions found in the report may not have developed under treatment with the products. The patient's events may be attributable to the underlying malignancy.
